definition: to raise aloft with both hands/(of two or more people) to carry sth together
old variant of 扛[gang1]
to carry on one's shoulder/(fig.) to take on (a burden, duty etc)
"hand" radical in Chinese characters (Kangxi radical 64), occurring in 提, 把, 打 etc
work/worker/skill/profession/trade/craft/labor
(argot) gang leader
to carry on the shoulder

sentences.english: And if war comes do such men as these shoulder the musket and go into the trenches?
sentences.chinese: 但一旦战争来临，这类人会肩扛步枪进入战壕吗？

sentences.english: Worry is like carrying a load of feathers we think are lead.
sentences.chinese: 焦虑就像是我们扛著一包羽毛，却认为是铅。

sentences.english: Will you help me to carry this big box upstairs.
sentences.chinese: 请你帮我把这个大箱了扛到楼上去好吗？

sentences.english: I took him on my shoulder and then carried him down the hill.
sentences.chinese: 后来发现我扛不动他，就去借了一匹马，驼着他下山。

sentences.english: He set out with the long fishing pole on his shoulder.
sentences.chinese: 他扛上鱼杆出发了，两只狗紧随其后。

sentences.english: They started off, and this time the hare carried the tortoise till the riverbank.
sentences.chinese: 它们一起出发，这次可是兔子扛著乌龟，直到河边。

sentences.english: They took the young men to grind, and the children fell under the wood.
sentences.chinese: 少年人扛磨石，孩童背木柴，都绊跌了。

sentences.english: The old farmer walked towards the field, hoe on shoulder.
sentences.chinese: 这位老农民肩扛锄头朝田里走去。

sentences.english: He helped her (to)carry the bag upstairs.
They turned to see the carpenter raise his toolbox on his shoulder.
sentences.chinese: 他们转过身，看到木匠把他的木工箱扛到了肩膀上。

sentences.english: After all, a smartphone with a camera is a far more common find in a blogger's pocket than a stand-alone video camera.
sentences.chinese: 毕竟智能手机装在口袋里要比扛部相机方便多了。

sentences.english: Solomon had seventy thousand carriers and eighty thousand stonecutters in the hills
sentences.chinese: 所罗门用七万扛抬的，八万在山上凿石头的。

sentences.english: Yao wears this mantle of fame quite well on his massive 7 foot 6 inch frame.
sentences.chinese: 然而，姚用他7尺六英寸的身躯很好的扛了起来。

sentences.english: And home we brought you shoulder-high.
sentences.chinese: 我们高高的扛著你回府。

sentences.english: He heaved the heavy box into the wagon .
sentences.chinese: 他把这个很重的箱于扛到了货车上。

sentences.english: Will help a few people came through the painting downstairs , propped up by the three years .
sentences.chinese: 几个人帮忙将这幅作品扛到楼下，由三个人撑起来。

definition: to lift/to carry in one's hand/Taiwan pr. [ling1]
to carry on the shoulder
to support/to prop up/to push or move with a pole/to maintain/to open or unfurl/to fill to bursting point/brace/stay/support
heavy burden/difficult task/great responsibility
carrying pole and the loads on it/burden/task/responsibility/CL:副[fu4]
to undertake/to carry/to shoulder/to take responsibility
picul (100 catties, 50 kg)/two buckets full/carrying pole and its load/classifier for loads carried on a shoulder pole
hard/stiff/strong/firm/resolutely/doggedly/good (quality)/able (person)/(of food) filling/substantial
to be unable to carry/lift (sth heavy)
to make oneself do sth in spite of adversity, pain etc
to bear/to support/to inherit
to swing (one's arms, a heavy object)/to wave (a sword, one's fists)/to fling (money)
to select
to resist/to hold back/to stop/to ward off/to withstand
to cause sth to collapse under the weight/(fig.) to overwhelm
to take on (a responsibility)
to move (i.e. relocate oneself)/to move (sth relatively heavy or bulky)/to shift/to copy indiscriminately
to withstand/to stand up to
